The production of 2-EH is similar to the past production of 2-PH so most of the existing equipment will be reused.  The 2-EH Unit will implement a Level 3 Risk Management Program as did the past 2-PH Unit.  

 



The Plasticizer (PX) Unit originally started up in 2007 and after some modification will be restarted in 2017 after the 2-EH Unit is started.  The PX Unit does not utilize threshold quantities of any substance on the EPA's List of Regulated Substances.  



The plant is located in Harris County adjacent to Route 225 on the Houston Ship Channel.



The 2-EH Unit will utilize substances that are on the EPA's List of Regulated Substances.  Following is a list of these substances:

The plant accidental release prevention programs and the contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to the employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The plant is in full compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  This standard is a fully comprehensive prevention program designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  The plant takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals through the requirements of OSHA's PSM Standard.  The plant's management systems address each of the key areas of this successful prevention program including:



* Process safety information

* Process hazard analysis

* Operating procedures

* Training

* Mechanical i

ntegrity

* Management of change

* Pre-startup safety review

* Compliance audits

* Incident investigation

* Employee participation

* Hot work permit

* Contractors



These elements of the prevention program work to prevent accidental chemical releases.  The plant management and employees are committed to the standards that these management systems establish for the way to conduct business.  The system contains specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that the plant is meeting these high standards for accident prevention.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at the plant.  There were no accidental chemical releases of covered substances that resulted in onsite or offsite injuries or property damage from July 11, 2011 to July 26, 2016 when this updated Executive Summary was submitted.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



An integrated emergency response / contingency plan is maintained which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  The plant program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plant coordinates the plan with the Houston area Channel Industries Mutual Aid Organization (CIMA) and the local community emergency response plans.



RECENT CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Since 1999, the plant has implemented several projects to improve the fire protection systems, including repairing and upgrading fireproofing, and replacing underground firewater pipelines.  The plant purchased a "Quick-Attack Fire Truck" and an "Emergency-Response Trailer" to add capability to the already existing fire truck and emergency response equipment.  Pipeline isolation valves were installed to the feedstock pipeline as part of the past project to convert the 2-EH Unit to 2-PH.  More recently, in 2013, the Confined Sp

ace Entry Procedure, was updated with ventilation requirements for welding operations in confined spaces.  Also, the Hot Work Procedure, Safe Work Permit Procedure, and Line Breaking Procedure were updated with the "4-Eyes" principle where at least two or more individuals (equipment operator/owner and individual performing the work) assess tasks in order to ensure that all hazards are identified and eliminated or controlled.
